title: Biotech IPOs Offer a Lesson in Risk Management
text:
Text size

David Schenkein, a general partner at GV, the venture-capital arm of Google parent Alphabet (ticker: GOOGL) and co-head of GV’s life science team, has been on both sides of the board room. In 2013, Schenkein, a medical oncologist, took Agios Pharmaceuticals (AGIO) public as its CEO. In a recent interview with Barron’s, Schenkein, a panelist on Barron’s biotech roundtable, discussed what he learned from his experience at Agios, where he remains executive chairman. Agios shares have returned more than 90% since their IPO.

Barron’s: What lessons can you point to from orchestrating Agios’ initial public offering?

David Schenkein: The first was the importance of leadership, and I don’t just mean at the top of the organization. It is important to make sure you brought in the right team in the C-suite, and to remember that great leadership is leadership throughout the organization. A lot of people forget about that as they build their companies.

The other component of that leadership lesson is the value of communication, not just internally. When you become a public company, you’re doing a lot of external communication. One of the things that I learned is the importance of having a consistent way of communicating whatever you’re doing: In your communication, are you going to be conservative? Are you going to be over-promise, under-deliver? What is your thermometer going to look like?

It is really important that you set that tone early with investors. I sat down with investors on [Agios’s] IPO road show and told them that we were going to be relatively conservative in the way we would announce our data. We’re going to wait until we have a story to tell you so you can understand it and make an investment decision.

The third lesson is the value of culture within an organization. I see some entrepreneurs who aren’t focused enough on building the appropriate culture. And that is critically important when you make that transition from private to public. If you have a consistent culture and everybody is grounded in what their north star is, and where they’re going, that helps the company achieve its long-term goals.

Now that you’re an investor in private companies that hope to one day go public, how has this experience been helpful?

Among those of us who have done this before, we can look at potential investment opportunities, and we can look with a critical eye at, what is the team like and what is management like. We can provide a resource and help those young management teams.

It sounds like you’re really focused on the management side of the early-stage biotech companies you’re looking at.

What makes a company great is going to be its management, and its culture, and, in the biotech space, its science. I’ve seen plenty of fantastic investors who only wanted to talk culture and management because they knew that if that was strong, the science would play out. Those are long-term investors. Short-term investors care about the data on patient No. 7.

How do you distinguish between an early-stage company that is worth thinking about, and an early-stage company that isn’t worth your time?

Fundamentally in our space, the first thing is the science. Do they understand the science, is it compelling, will it make a big impact for patients? I’m very patient-focused, and so I want to know, is this a company that is trying to do something that will have an incremental improvement, or a big improvement on patients’ lives? Both may be good investment opportunities, but that is the first thing that I focus on.

And the second thing, I go to the quality of the team that has been assembled. You can tell if a company is over-hyping something, and if they don’t really recognize how hard it is to do whatever they’re setting out to do.

Do people who don’t understand how hard the science will be really get to the point of having a meeting with you?

I’ve seen companies come in with expectations of what they’re going to achieve in a period of time that I view as potentially unrealistic.

Thanks, David.

description: GV partner David Schenkein took Agios Pharmaceuticals public in 2013. Here’s how the experience informs his work as a venture capitalist.
